title-group.article-title: Thermoelastic dynamic response for a long functionally graded hollow cylinder

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, Hunan University, Changsha, China
2Department of Engineering Mechanics, College of Mechanical & Vehicle Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha, China

author-notes.corresp: Hong-Liang Dai, State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, Hunan University, Changsha 410082, China. Email: hldai520@sina.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, a novel numerical method is presented to analyze the thermoelastic dynamic response of a long hollow cylinder made of functionally graded materials under radially symmetric dynamic mechanical and thermal loadings. That is utilizing finite difference method and Newmark method to solve the governing equation. The material of the functionally graded material hollow cylinder is assumed to change continuously along the thickness according to power-law distribution, except for a constant Poisson’s ratio, and the thermal boundary condition without internal heat source is considered. Comparisons between this paper’s results and the corresponding analytical results validate the solution proposed in this paper. Finally, the functionally graded material hollow cylinder under constant load and impulsive load are discussed in detail and many valuable thermoelastic dynamic characteristics are revealed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Functionally graded materials (FGMs) are microscopically inhomogeneous composite materials in which the mechanical properties vary smoothly and continuously from one surface to the other. FGMs as a new branch of materials are used for designing structures that can withstand suddenly applied thermomechanical loads. Among the FGM structures, cylinder components have been of special interest.

In recent years, thermoelastic analysis of FGM hollow cylinder structures has attracted many researchers’ efforts. In 1999, Yang1 considered a joined FGM cylinder and presented an analytical solution for the calculation of the time- and temperature-dependent stresses in FGM for the elastic and creep behaviors of the material. In 2002, Jabbari et al.2 used the direct method to solve the heat conduction and Navier equations of a FGM hollow cylinder due to radially symmetric loads. In 2005, by using a multilayered approach based on the theory of laminated composites, the solutions of temperature, displacements and thermal/mechanical stress in a FGM hollow cylinder with finite length were presented by Shao3; Shen and Noda4 investigated the postbucking of FGM cylindrical shells under combined axial and radial mechanical loads in thermal environments. In 2006, Galerkin finite element and Newmark methods (NMs) were combined to solve the Navier equation of FGM hollow cylinders under dynamic load by Shakeri et al.5 Dai and Wang6 presented exact solutions for magnetothermoelastic problem of FGM hollow structures subjected to mechanical loads in 2007. In the same year, Melanie et al.7 presented the analytical solution to the problem of uniform heating of an FGM sphere, whose elastic module and thermal expansion coefficient vary linearly with the radius. In 2008, Radu et al.8 applying a finite Hankel transform and some properties of Bessel functions addressed the solution for elastic thermal stress components in a hollow cylinder under sinusoidal transient thermal loading; Shao and Ma9 presented thermomechanical stresses in functionally graded circular hollow cylinders with linearly increasing boundary temperature. The exact solution of steady-state two-dimensional axisymmetric mechanical and thermal stresses for a short hollow FGM cylinder was developed by Jabbari et al.10 in 2009. In 2010, Shariyat et al.11 analyzed the nonlinear thermoelasticity, vibration and stress wave propagation analyses of thick-walled FGM cylinders; Peng and Li12 presented a new method for analyzing steady thermal stresses in a FGM hollow cylinder in which the boundary value problem associated with a thermoelastic problem was converted to a Fredholm integral equation; by means of a second-order point-collocation method, Shariyat et al.13 analyzed the nonlinear transient thermal stress and elastic wave propagation of thick temperature-dependent FGM cylinders. In 2011, Dai et al.14 presented the exact solution for the one-dimensional steady-state magnetothermoelastic stresses and perturbation of magnetic field vector in a FGM hollow sphere; Ying and Wang15 obtained an exact solution for two-dimensional elastodynamic analysis of finite hollow cylinder excited by nonuniform thermal shock. However, to the authors’ knowledge, combining finite difference method (FDM)16 with NM17 to analyze the thermoelastic dynamic responses of a long hollow FGM cylinder, the material properties of which follow the power-law distribution, have not been studied in the previous literatures.

In this paper, by means of FDM and NM, the thermoelastic dynamic responses of a long hollow FGM cylinder due to radially symmetric dynamic mechanical load and thermal load are investigated. By comparing some results in this paper with the corresponding analytical ones,2 the solution proposed in this paper is validated. Finally, as numerical examples, the FGM hollow cylinder under constant load and impulsive load are discussed in detail, and many thermoelastic dynamic characteristics are obtained, which will be of wide significance in the designing of smart structures in engineering.

sec.title: Statement of the problem and basic formulations
sec.p: Consider a long FGM hollow cylinder with varying material properties in the thickness direction. The thickness, inner and outer radii of the cylindrical structure are, respectively, denoted by H, a and b. The FGM hollow cylinder is subjected to axisymmetrical, uniformly distributed dynamic loads and thermal loads. For this axisymmetric plane strain problem, the deformations are defined with reference to cylindrical coordinate system (r, θ, z).

The material of the cylindrical structure is graded through the r-direction, and a combined ceramic–metal material is considered in this paper. The inner surface is pure ceramic and the outer surface is pure metal. The mechanical properties of the hollow cylinder are varying continuously through the thickness with a desired variation of the volume fractions of the two materials. The Poisson’s ratio ν is assumed to be constant, while the elasticity modulus E, mass density ρ, thermal expansion coefficient α and thermal conduction coefficient k are assumed to change continuously along the thickness according to power-law distribution as follows (1)P=(Pm-Pc)(r-ab-a)n+Pc where P denotes material property and n denotes a nonnegative volume fraction exponent characterizing the distributions of material properties. The n = 0 and n = +∞, respectively, correspond to an isotropic homogeneous cylinder with P = Pm and P = Pc. Subscripts m and c refer to the metal and ceramic constituents, respectively. Figure 1 shows the volume fraction distribution of metallic phase through the thickness for different values of n. Figure 1.
Distributions of modulus of elasticity of the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder.

The stress–strain relations for plane-strain conditions are (2a)σr=c1(r)∂u∂r+c2(r)ur-λT(r) (2b)σθ=c2(r)∂u∂r+c1(r)ur-λT(r) (2c)σz=v(σr+σθ)-EαT(r) where u(r) is the radial displacement, σi(i = r, θ, z) denotes the stress tensors in the cylindrical coordinate, T(r) is the temperature change, ci(r) (i = 1, 2) are elastic stiffness coefficients related to E and ν as (3)c1(r)=E(1-v)(1+v)(1-2v),c2(r)=Ev(1+v)(1-2v) and (4)λ=Eα1-2v
The dynamic equilibrium equation of the hollow cylinder, disregarding the body forces, is (5)∂σr∂r+σr-σθr=ρ∂2u∂t2

Substituting equations (1)–(4) into equation (5), yields (6)∂2u∂r2+f1(r)∂u∂r+f2(r)u=f3(r)∂2u∂t2+f4(r) where (7)f1(r)=1c1(r)∂c1∂r+1r, f2(r)=1rc1(r)∂c2∂r-1r2,f3(r)=ρ(r)c1(r), f4(r)=1c1(r)∂λ∂rT(r)+λ(r)c1(r)∂T(r)∂r

The mechanic boundary conditions and the initial conditions of the cylinder are taken as (8a)σr(a,t)=qa(t),τrθ(a,t)=0 (8b)σr(b,t)=qb(t),τrθ(b,t)=0 (9)u·(r,0)=0,u(r,0)=0 where τrθ denotes the shear stress.

sec.title: Heat conduction problem
sec.p: The heat conduction equation in the steady-state condition for the one-dimensional problem in polar coordinates and the thermal boundary conditions without internal heat source for the FGM hollow cylinder are given, respectively, as12 (10)1r∂∂r[rk(r)∂T(r)∂r]=0,(a≤r≤b) (11a)C11T(a)+C12T'(a)=ζ1 (11b)C21T(b)+C22T'(b)=ζ2 where k = k(r) is the thermal conduction coefficient, cij(i, j = 1, 2) are the constant thermal parameters relative to the conduction and convection coefficients, ζj ( j = 1, 2) are known constants on the inner and outer radii of the double-layered hollow cylinder, respectively.

By solving equation (10), yields (12)T(r)=A∫ar1δk(δ)dδ+B where constants A and B can be determined using the boundary conditions equations (11a) and (11 b) (13a)A=C11ζ2-C21ζ1C11C21∫ab1δk(δ)dδ+C11C22bk(b)-C12C21ak(a) (13b)B=ζ1[∫ab1δk(δ)dδ+C22bk(b)]-C12ak(a)ζ2C11C21∫ab1δk(δ)dδ+C11C22bk(b)-C12C21ak(a)

Here, consider one representative case where the temperature changes at the inner and outer surfaces are prescribed. Denote that ζ1 = Ta, ζ2 = Tb, using C11 = C21 = 1, C12 = C22 = 0, then yields (14)T(r)=Tb-Ta∫ab1δk(δ)dδ∫ar1δk(δ)dδ+Ta
For this FGM hollow cylinder, it is assumed that the thermal conduction coefficient k(r) reads (15)k(r)=(km-kc)(r-ab-a)n+kc,a≤r≤b
The temperature dependence of the material properties does not take into account in the present paper. As indicated in the work by Miyamoto,18 this will not have a significant effect on results.

sec.title: Solution of the problem
sec.p: In the section, the FDM and NM are, respectively, used in the space domain and time domain to solve the dynamic equilibrium equation of the FGM cylinder.

sec.title: FDM in the space domain
sec.p: Step 1. Generate a grid. The radial thickness is divided into m portions, so there are (m + 1) nodes along the radial direction and the thickness of each portion h is (b – a)/m. If the inner surface is defined to correspond to the node i = 0 and the outer surface to the node i = m, then between i = 0 and i = m, the nodes are i = 1, i = 2,…, i = m = 1 in sequence. At node i, the corresponding value of radius is r(i) = a + ih (i = 0, 1, 2,…, m). For the sake of better understanding, node i will be named as ri in the following analysis.

Step 2. Substitute the derivatives in equation (6) with finite difference schemes. To make sure that the error is proportional to h2, below we list three finite difference formulas to approximate the first-order derivative of function u(ri, t).16
The forward finite difference (16)u'(r0,t)=12h[-3u(r0,t)+4u(r1,t)-u(r2,t)]+O(h2)
The backward finite difference (17)u'(rm,t)=12h[3u(rm,t)-4u(rm-1,t)+u(rm-2,t)]+O(h2)
The central finite difference (18)u'(ri,t)=12h[u(ri+1,t)-u(ri-1,t)] +O(h2),(i=1,2,…,m-1)
The central finite difference scheme for the second-order derivative u″(ri, t) is (19)u″(ri,t)=1h2[u(ri+1,t)-2u(ri,t)+u(ri-1,t)] +O(h2),(i=1,2,…,m-1)

When considering terms related to the temperature, such as T(r) and ∂T(r)/∂r in the calculation, the temperature distribution function is needed. However, by substituting equation (15) into equation (12), the corresponding indefinite integration is difficult to be solved. So the FDM is adopted.
The central finite difference (20)T'(ri)=12h1[T(ri+1)-T(ri-1)] +O(h12),(i=1,2,…,m1-1)
The forward finite difference (21)T'(r0)=12h1[-3T(r0)+4T(r1)-T(r2)]+O(h12)
The backward finite difference (22)T'(rm1)=12h1[3T(rm1)-4T(rm1-1)+T(rm1-2)]+O(h12)
Then for the inner layer of the FGM hollow cylinder, the left side of equation (6) can be reduced to a linear system of algebraic expressions.

sec.title: NM in the time domain
sec.p: Average acceleration method (ξ = 1/4, γ = 1/2) is chosen in this paper. The variables ξ and γ are numerical parameters that control both the stability of the method and the amount of numerical damping introduced into the system by the method. For γ = 1/2, there is no numerical damping. The time domain is divided into time steps jΔt (j = 1, 2, 3,…). The approximation of u(ri, t + Δt), u·(ri,t+Δt) and u··(ri,t+Δt), when i = 1, 2,…, m-1, are expressed as17 (23)u(ri,t+Δt)=u(ri,t)+u·(ri,t)Δt+[(1-2λ)u··(ri,t) +2λu··(ri,t+Δt)]Δt22 (24)u·(ri,t+Δt)=u·(ri,t)+[(1-γ)u··(ri,t) +γu··(ri,t+Δt)]Δt (25)u··(ri,t+Δt)=1λΔt2[u(ri,t+Δt)-u(ri,t)] -1λΔtu·(ri,t)-(12λ-1)u··(ri,t)
Considering initial conditions and substituting equations (23)–(25) into equation (9), yields u··(ri,0)=0.
Then, when k = 1, (26)u··(ri,kΔt)=u··(ri,Δt)=1λΔt2u(ri,Δt) (27)u·(ri,kΔt)=u·(ri,Δt)=γΔtu··(ri,Δt)

When k ≥ 2, (28)u··(ri,kΔt)=1λΔt2[u(ri,kΔt)-u(ri,(k-1)t)] -1λΔtu·(ri,(k-1)t)-(12λ-1)u··(ri,(k-1)t) (29)u·(ri,kΔt)=u·(ri,(k-1)Δt) +[(1-γ)u··(ri,(k-1)Δt) +γu··(ri,kΔt)]Δt where i = 1, 2,…, m – 1 in equations (23)–(29). Then, the right side of equation (6) can be reduced to a linear system of algebraic expressions too.
When i = 1, 2,…, m – 1, combining FDM with NM, as represented above, equation (6) turns into a linear system of (m – 1) equations.

Finally, considering the boundary conditions, equation (8), and substituting equations (16) and (17) into equation (8), yields (30)σr(a,t)=c1(a)12h1[-3u(r0,t)+4u(r1,t)-u(r2,t)] +c2(a)u(r0,t)a-λ(a)T(a)=qa(t) (31)σr(b,t)=c1(b)12h[3u(rm1,t)-4u(rm1-1,t)+u(rm1-2,t)] +c2(b)u(rm1,t)b-λ(b)T(b)=qb(t) where qa(t) and qb(t) show the mechanic loads at the inner and outer surface of the FGM hollow cylinder, respectively.

Combining equations (30)–(31) with the aforementioned (m – 1) equations and solving the m + 1 equations, so u(ri,Δt) (i = 0, 1, 2,…, m – 1, m) can be obtained easily. Then, by using an iterative method, u(ri, jΔt) (i = 0, 1, 2,…, m – 1, m; j = 0, 1, 2,…) can all be obtained as we desired. During the computing process, debugging for h and Δt is needed to satisfy good accuracy. In this paper, the computing program is verified by the analytical method, and a good agreement is observed.

sec.title: Numerical results and discussion
sec.p: In the following numerical examples, consider a long FGM hollow cylinder of inner radius a = 0.25 m and outer radius b = 0.5 m. The material parameters at the inner radius (silicon nitride [Si3N4]) are Ec = 348.43 GPa, ρc = 2370 kg/m3, Kc = 13.723 W/mK, αc = 5.8723 × 10–6/K and the material parameters at the outer radius (SUS304) are Em = 201.04 GPa, ρm = 8166 kg/m3, Km = 15.379 W/mK and αm = 12.330 × 10–6/K.

Example 1. To validate the presented solution of the dynamic problem, comparisons between the paper’s results and the existing analytical results are present. Considering the same conditions as the reference,2 from Figure 2, the good agreements are clearly found, and the boundary conditions are satisfied well, which indicate the efficiency of the method developed in this paper for addressing the thermoelastic problem of the FGM hollow cylinder. Figure 2.
Distributions of stresses of the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder compared to the corresponding analytical results.

Example 2. The effect of the gradient index (n) and the thermal environment (Ta, Tb) of the Si3N4/SUS304 FGM hollow cylinder’s performance are discussed in this example. Consider the FGM hollow cylinder has pressure on its inner surface, and the mechanical boundary conditions are assumed as (32a)qa(t)=-P0H(t) (32b)qb(t)=0 where P0 = 20 MPa and H(t) expresses the Heaviside function.

sec.title: The effect of the gradient index n
sec.p:
The temperature conditions of the FGM hollow cylinder are taken as Ta = 100 K, Tb = 0 K. Temperature distributions along the radial direction with different n are showed in Figure 3, it is seen from the curves that with the variation of n, the temperature (T/Ta) varies slightly at the same point of the FGM hollow cylinder. From n = 0.2 to n = 20, the biggest difference in T/Ta is less than 0.01. Figure 3.
Distributions of temperature in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder with different n.

Figures 4–6 show the radial displacement, radial stress and hoop stress of the FGM hollow cylinder with n = 0.2, 0.5, 1, 5 and 20, respectively. From these figures, it is known that if n of the FGM cylinder is appropriate, the radial displacement and the stresses in the structure will vary smoothly as desired. Due to the direct influence of n on the material properties of the FGM hollow cylinder, n produces a significant effect on the displacement and stress of the FGM hollow cylinder too. From Figure 4, it is known that, from n = 0.2 to n = 20, the radial displacement of the FGM hollow cylinder decreases with the increasing of n, but the influence of n on du/dr is little. From Figure 5, it is easy to find that the numerical results satisfy the boundary stress conditions very well, in addition, when n < 1, because the effect of temperature on metal is larger than on ceramics, the bigger value of n, the less metallic of the hollow cylinder, then the smaller value of σr. When n > 1, the metallic of the hollow cylinder becomes weaker, then with the increasing of n, the corresponding radial stress increases. From Figure 6, it is seen that the value of the hoop stress is much larger than the value of radial stress. When n < 0.5, the hoop stresses of the points close to the inner surface decrease rapidly, and when n is much small, the hoop stresses of the points close to the inner surface are huge. The hoop stress of the FGM hollow with n = 5 is close to that with n = 20, and it reveals that for large values of n, the hoop stress of one point turns to be constant, so do radial stress and radial displacement, which are clearly shown in Figures 5 and 6. So, in this paper, the largest value of n is chosen to be 20. Figure 4.
Distributions of radial displacement in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder with different n, where Ta = 100 K. Figure 5.
Distributions of radial stress in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder with different n, where Ta = 100 K. Figure 6.
Distributions of hoop stress in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder with different n, where Ta = 100 K.

sec.title: The effect of the temperature condition
sec.p:
To investigate the effect of the temperature conditions to the working performance of the FGM hollow cylinder, radial displacement, radial stress and hoop stress of the FGM hollow cylinder with n = 1, Tb = 0 K and Ta = –100 K, 0 K, 100 K, 200 K and 300 K are discussed, respectively, which are shown in Figures 7–9. Figure 7.
Distributions of radial displacement in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder with different Ta, where n = 1. Figure 9.
Distributions of hoop stress in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder with different Ta, where η = 1 and n = 1.

From Figure 7, it is seen easily that the radial displacement increases with the increase of the absolute value of Ta, indicated by symbol ΔT = |Ta|. When ΔT = 0, |du/dr| is close to zero. With the increasing of ΔT, |du/dr| increases in the FGM hollow cylinder. It is easily seen from Figures 8 and 9 that ΔT has a significant impact on the stresses of the FGM hollow cylinder too. With the increasing of ΔT, both the |dσr/dr| and |dσθ/dr| increases, and then the maximum value of the radial stress and the hoop stress increases. Moreover, Figure 8 reveals that the maximum value of the radial stress occurs at the plane where r/a near to 1.4, while Figure 9 reveals that maximum value of the hoop stress occurs at the surfaces of the FGM hollow cylinder, and the zero hoop stress appears at the plane near to the middle plane of the FGM hollow cylinder. Figure 8.
Distributions of radial stress in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder with different Ta, where n = 1.

Example 3. Dynamic behaviors of the FGM hollow cylinder when exited by impulsive internal pressure are discussed in this example. The mechanical boundary conditions are assumed as qb(t) = 0 and (33a)qa(t)=-P1t,whent≤0.001s (33b)qa(t)=0,whent>0.001s where P1 = 4 GPa/s. The cylinder is unloaded abruptly at t = 0.001 s.
(1) No temperature change considered

Figures 10–12 show the time responses of the radial displacement, radial stress and hoop stress of the FGM hollow cylinder at different radial locations. From these three figures, it is easy to find that the amplitude of the free vibration is almost equal to the corresponding value as the pressure is abruptly dismissed, and it decreases from the inner surface to the outer surface, for the mechanical pressure is loaded on the inner surface. The equilibrium positions of the vibrations are u = 0, σr = 0 and σθ = 0, respectively, when Ta = 0 K and Tb = 0 K. Comparing Figure 11 with Figure 13, it indicates that the hoop stress is larger than the corresponding radial stress. As the curves shown in Figure 11, the boundary conditions in this example are met well, at the same time, the rules of the curves in Figures 10–12 all accord with the variation characteristics obtained by Shakeri et al.;5 thus, the correctness of the numerical results is clarified again. Figure 10.
Response histories of radial displacement in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder at different radial points, where n = 1 and Ta = 0 K. Figure 11.
Response histories of radial stress in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder at different radial points, where n = 1 and Ta = 0 K. Figure 12.
Response histories of hoop stress in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder at different radial points, where n = 1 and Ta = 0 K. Figure 13.
Response histories of radial displacement in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder at different radial points, where n = 1 and Ta = 100 K. Figure 14.
Response histories of radial stress in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder at different radial points, where n = 1 and Ta = 100 K.
(2) Temperature change is considered

Figures 13–15 depict the time responses of the radial displacement, radial stress and hoop stress in the FGM hollow cylinder with Ta = 100 K, Tb = 0 K and n = 1. Comparing these three figures with the former three ones, it is found that the amplitudes of the vibrations during the loaded time (t < 0.001 s) are close to those after the time when the pressure is suddenly disappeared (t≥0.001s) in these three figures. It indicates that when the FGM hollow cylinder works in high-temperature environment, the thermoelastic characteristics must to be considered, for they will be the predominant reasons for the failure of the smart hollow cylindrical structure. What is more, it is clearly observed that due to the temperature change in the hollow cylinder, the equilibrium positions of the vibrations are not u = 0 or σr = 0 or σθ = 0 anymore. Figure 15.
Response histories of hoop stress in the functionally graded material (FGM) hollow cylinder at different radial points, where n = 1 and Ta = 100 K.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: (1) In the paper, a new numerical method is proposed to analyze the thermoelastic dynamic response of a long FGM hollow cylinder, which is utilizing FDM and NM to solve the governing equation of the FGM hollow cylinder under dynamic loads. Comparisons between this paper’s results and the analytical results2 validate the solution presented in this paper.

(2) For the FGM hollow cylinder, as n influences the material properties directly, n produces a significant effect on the thermoelastic dynamic responses of the FGM hollow cylinder too. In this paper, the FGM hollow cylinders with 0.2 ≤ n ≤ 20 are considered. It reveals that (1) the radial displacement of the FGM hollow cylinder decreases with the increasing of n, and n has little influence on du/dr; (2) for the normal stresses, when n < 1, the smaller value of n, the bigger value of σr or σθ, and when n > 1, the bigger value of n, the bigger value of σr or σθ; (3) for the hoop stress, when n < 1, the hoop stresses of the points close to the inner surface decrease rapidly, and when n is much smaller, the hoop stresses of the points close to the inner surface are much larger; (4) the numerical results reveal that the radial displacement, radial stress and hoop stress of the FGM hollow cylinder with n = 5 are close to those with n = 20, respectively, which indicates that for large values of n, the corresponding value of one point turns to be constant, so in this paper, the largest value of n is chosen to be 20.

(3) Temperature conditions place a significant role when investigating the thermoelastic dynamic responses of the FGM hollow cylinder, with the increasing of ΔT, the values of |du/dr|, |dσr/dr| and |dσθ/dr| increase, and then the maximum values of u, σr and σθ increase. In addition, the vibration caused by the high temperature is much conspicuous than that caused by the mechanical loads. So, when the FGM hollow cylinder structure works in high temperature environment, the thermoelastic characteristics must be considered seriously, for they will be the predominant reasons for the failure of the smart hollow cylindrical structure.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors wish to thank reviewers for their valuable comments and the funding by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No.11072077), State key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body (Grant No.734215002) and the central colleges of basic scientific research and operational costs (funded by the Hunan University).

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
